You could make it faster by gyrocopter. But even by truck, its just overnight between Manhattan skyscrapers and Southside Virginia fields. Incidentally, the modern mechanized hay har vesting you see here cuts man-hours by about half. Its one of many reasons this area has growing reserves of manpower to staff new industries. Ask VEPCO for figures on the proven trainability and high per-dollar productivity of these workers. Ask, too, for plant site data and economic studies on this land of pleasant living and Southern production savings thats right on top of your richest markets. Write, wire or phone. J. Randolph Perrow, Manager, Area Development, Electric Building, Richmond, Virginia 23209 Telephone Milton 9-1411 Area Code 703 VIRGINIA ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY

Yon howled yonr head off when i home town player, bat on shoulder, let a perfect pitch wham into the catchers mitt for the third strike. Well, youd have the same right to howl if yon saw the man who works next to yon miss the ball on this tax redaction business. By taking the extra money and putting it into United States savings bonds through the payroll savings plan he actually would be hitting a home run for security for self and country. Your country needs millions of savors now to preserve the nations security. Americas security is your security. If. S. document.text: Without nuclear power in the first seven months of 1974, fuel costs for Virginia Electric and Power Company customers would have been at least 45 million higher, Stanley Ragone, Vepco Senior Vice President, Power, said today. Surry Nuclear Power Station accounted for more than 25 per cent of the electricity generat ed by Vepco during the first seven months, just as projected in 1970, Mr. Ragone said. If we had had two fossil fuel plants at Surry instead of nuclear during that same period, the fuel cost would have been about 70 million. Allow ing for the higher initial costs of  nuclear facilities and the cost of operation, the net effect is a reduction in cost per kilowatt- hour of 2.5 mills or a quarter of a cent. The amount of oil required for two fossil fuel units at Surrey would have been tre mendous. Comparable oil - fired units would have consumed about seven millions barrels, or about 294 million gallons, to produce the same amount of energy generated by the two nuclear units. Mr. Ragone pointed out that during each month of the second quarter of 1974 Sury Unit 1 produced more electrici ty than any other nuclear unit in the world. Fuel costs will be reduced even more, Mr. Ragone said, as the units mature and account for an even greater output of kilowatthours. During July arid August, TJnit 1 at Surry recorded a 74.6 per cent performance level. Surry 2 during those two months performed at 68.4 per cent. The national average of performance by all nuclear units for the first six months was 53.7 per cent. Surry at 50.9 per cent was slightly below the national average for the same period. However, six month comparisons are not very significant, Mr. Ragone warn ed. We scheduled one unit at Surry out of service for maintenance during the Spring in order to avoid having it out of service during the Summer

document.text: WELL DIGGER CAUSES POWER STOPPAGE Appomattox suffered from a loss electric power for approximately one hour and forty-five minutes Monday afternoon. The local Virginia Electric and Power Company representative stated that it was caused by a breakage in the line near Prospect. The break was caused by a well digger coming into contact with the fine and breaking all four conductors.

document.text: We THE PEOPLE of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, establish justic, insure domestic tranqui lity, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare, and secure the bless ings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the United States of America. VEPCO Plans Rate Increase Virginia Electric and Power Company has announced plans to increase rates paid by the rural electric cooperatives, municipalities and one private utility the company serves on a wholesale basis. These wholesale customers, whose rates are under the jurisdiction of the Federal Power Commission FPC, were notified of the proposed increase in a letter which was sent yesterday by Robert S. Gay, Vepco manager of rates. In the letter, Mr. Gay said, The basic objective of our company continues to be to provide to all our customers the best possible electric service at the lowest practicable costs. However, our cost increases can no longer be absorbed. We feel it is essential, In order to continue to provide reliable service, that our rate for electric service to our rural electric cooperative, municipal and privately owned utility customers must be increased.

document.text: VIRGINIA In the Circuit Court of Appomattox County Virginia Electric and Power Company, a Virginia Corpora tion, Petitioner, v. John LeGrande Baker, E t Al, and 0.528 Acre, More or Less, of Land, Located in Appomat tox County, Virginia, Defen dants. NOTICE BY PUBLICATION LAW NO. 2117 To Whom It May Concern Pursuant to an Order entered on the 11th day of December, 1981, this Notice is hereby given _ _____ _ In ,this proceeding the Petitioner seeks to acquire by condemnation certain perpetual rights, privileges and easement of right of way over, under, upon and across a certain piece or parcel of land situated in Appomattox County, Virginia, for the uses and purposes of the Petitioner in the laying, construction, operation and maintenance of electric trans mission and distribution facili ties consisting of one or more lines of poles, towers, structu res, cables, conduits and pipes, together with all w ires, manholès,  handholes, attach ments, equipment, accessories and appurtenances desirable in connection therewith, all of which are described mbre particularly in the Petition and by the exhibit-attached thereto on file in the Officé of the Clerk of this Court, to which reference is hereby made for a full and accurate description thereof and for the appoint ment of commissioners to ascertain just compensation to the Owners of any estate or interest in the property to be taken or affected as a result of the taking and use there of by thé Petitioner. For such purposes, the Petitioner will apply to this  Court, sitting at Appomattox, Virginia, on the 23fd day of February, 1982, at 10 oclock a.m ., or as soon thereafter as Petitioner may be heard, for the appointment of commis-. sioners to ascertain just compensation as aforesaid. And it appearing by Affidavit filed according to law that the follow ing Owners are pot residents of the State Of Virginia Charles Edward Hen derson, Charlotte P . Henderson and Maggie Bell. IT IS ORDERED that the aforesaid Owners do appear within ten 10 days after due publication of this Order in the Clerks Office of this Court and do what is necessary to protect their interests. IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that if any of the above named Owners desire to assert any objection or defense to the taking or damaging of their property or to the jurisdiction of the Court to hear the Case and to proceed with the appointment of commissioners, they shall file their answer and grounds of defense designat ing the property in which they claim to be interested, the grounds of any objection or defense to the taking or damaging of-their property or to the jurisdiction of the Court to hear the case and to proceed with th e , appointment of commissioners for the deter mination of just compensation. Should any such Owners fail to file their answer and grounds of defense as hereinabove provided, such failure shall not preclude the Owners. front appearing on the date set for the appointment of commissio ners nor from presenting evidence as to valuation and damage nor from sharing in the award of just compensation according to their interest therein or otherwise protecting their rights, but such failure shall preclude such Owners from any other defense by way of pleas in bar, or otherwise. An extract. Teste Barhara R. Williams Clerk 8012-16-2tc

document.text: Virginia Electric and Power Company UDC Program Thursday Night

Virginia Electric and Power Company today named Charles T. Snellings director of pur chases. He succeeds L. E. Davis, who retires April 1. Robert A. McKay, Jr., mechanical super visor at Vepcos Possum Point  power station, will succeed Snell ings as assistant to the purchas ing agent responsible for the pur-1 chase of fuels for electric steam 1 power generating stations. The 1 appointments are effective April 1 1.Snellings, formerly assistant to the purchasing agent, joined  Vepcos Purchasing Department in 1953 after several years with  the purchasing department of an engineering firm. His responsi bilities at Vepco have ben pri marily connected with the pur chase of fuels, principally coal, for the companys steam power ed generating stations. McKay, a native of Baltimore, Md., joined Vepco in 1940 as a statistician. He later served as efficiency engineer before he was named to his present post in 19- 61. He attended William and Mary College.

Virginia Electric and Power Company today filed with the State Corporation Commission a request to add a limited number of gas customers. In a letter accompanying the requested changes, Vepco Executive Vice President William W. Berry said that the Company will be able to sell an additional 170,000 MCF thousand cubic feet of gas beginning August 1,1978. With the improved natural gas supplies ana Vepcos newly acquired storage capability this additional load will not have a detrimental effect on our existing customers, he explained. Vepco presently serves 118, 657 residential, commercial, and industrial customers in the Tidewater area of Virginia. The additional 170,000 MCF will allow the Company to serve approximately 2,000 new customers. We expect to serve a combination of residential, small commercial, and industrial customers, said Mr. Berry. The limitations will be on the amount of gas we have available to sell additional 170,000 MCF a year and the location of the new customers. We will not be installing new gas mains but we will connect new customers to existing mains.

Virginia Electric and Power Company today filed an application with the Federal Power Commission for a substantial rate increase, re quested to be effective Jinuary 1, in an effort to gain a fair return on the investment necessary to serve its whole sale customers. In its application, Vepco requested an increase of about 30 per cent from 19 rural electric cooperatives and an increase of about 27 per cent from 21 municipalities and one private utility served on a wholesale basis. The request would yield a rate of return of 10.10 per cent on the companys investment necessary to serve the whole sale customers. This phase of Vepcos business accounted for about 11 percent of the total kilowatt hours sold by the company in 1973. Under the Federal Power Act, the Commission has the prerogative of permitting the rates to become effective as of January 1,1975, or postponing the effectiveness of the rates and ordering a hearing into their reasonableness. Any portion of the request im plemented on an interim basis, but not ultimately approved by the FPC, would be refunded with interest. E. B. Crutchfield, Vepco senior vice president, said that each month of delay in effective date of the requested rates would represent more than 1.5 million in revenue. Those revenues could never be recovered, Mr. Crutchfield said, The customers, on tne other hand, he pointed out, are protected because of the refund provision. He said for the test year ending  December 31, 1975, without a rate increase Vepco would earn a rate of return of 5.79 per cent from the cooperatives and 6,32 per cent from the municipalities and private utility. He pointed out that the companys testimony filed with the application would show that the company expenses have been the victim of severe inflation. In the past two years cost of

Virginia Electric and Power Company today filed a request with the Virginia State Corporation Commission for a temporary surcharge ef 12.17 per cent, or about 118 million on w annual basis. Stanley Ragroe, Vepco pre- rident, said the companys request  .. seeks only the rate relief necessary to make up for the deficiency below the approved rate of return which occurred in the 12-month period ending June 30, 1977, and to have our new nuclear unit at North Anna go in aarriee w ithout creating a much greater deficiency. Permanent rate relief in the range of tm addftkri right per cent or 80 million would be sought later this year, he said. He emphasized that the net impact on cuztomera would be less because nuclear fuel costs less than coal or ofl. Virginia Electric and Power Company today announced plans to sell approximately 50 mil lion of preferred stock and ap proximately five million shares of common stock in a public offering on September 27. The preferred stock will con sist of 500,000 shares at 100 par value. Both of the sales will be in negotiated transactions with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith Incorporated as the managing underwriter. In addition, the company an nounced plans to sell and lease back approximately 23 million of nuclear fuel for the first unit at the Surry Power Station. The company also plans to place a five-year note in the amount of 50 million. Both of these trans actions are expected to be con summated around the end of August. Proceeds from the foregoing transactions will be used to finance in part Vepcos 1972 construction budget of approxi mately 486 million. The companys most recent public offerings were in June, 1972, when it sold 100 million

Virginia Electric and Power Company héh presorted checks totaling 375,053 to county and city treasuréra in Vepcoa Southern Division in Payment of 1976 real estate and personal property taxes. The largest check of 54,176 went to Halifax County Treasurer, W. C- Anderson, Jr. Other counties receiving checks included Mecklenburg, 53,- 601 Campbell, 33,803 Pitts ylvania, 24,531 Prince Ed ward, 31,401 Nottoway, 18,- 738 Brunswick, 17.699 Lun enburg, 16,400 Greensville, 18,180 Buckingham, 19,078 Charlotte, 13,980 Cumber land, 19,520 Appom attox, 11,237- Amelia, 7,297 and Bedford, 1,843. Cities receiving checks in cluded South Boston, 25,736 and Emporia, 7,883. Vepcos Virginia state and local taxes for 1976 are estimated to total 65,800,000, an increase of 14,427,000 or 28.1 per cent over 1975. This includes 19,990,000 for proper ty taxes and 45,385,000 for tax on gross receipts.

Virginia Electric and Power Company has presented checks totaling 1370,073 to county and city treasurers in Vepcos Southern Division in payment of 1975 real estate and personal property taxes. The largest check of 55,731 went to Mecklenburg County Treasurer, Robert Gregory.

Virginia Electric and Power Company has announced the beginning of its summer peak reducing program. Hot Watch 95. Hot Watch-95, a voluntary program aimed at shifting the use of electricity away from the peak periods of electricity use, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. on weekdays, will go into effect on days when Vepcos meteorologist predicts temperatures of 95 degrees or above for the urban corridor. The urban corridor extends from Northern Virginia throu gh Richmond to Tidewater. This is the third summer for Hot Watch-95, said Hank Holloway, Advertising Mana ger. Because it is a voluntary program without immediate dollar reward it is hard to measure the results. The success of the program depends on the pace pur customers

Virginia Electric and Power Company has announced plans for an electrical outage for its customers in the Pamplin Area on Sat., Oct. 28, 1972 at 7 a.m. until approximately 10 a.m. Vepco customers affected will be on and near Highway Number 47 from the Pamplin Substation south to the inter section of Route 671 and east along Route 671 to the inter section of Route 663, near Dar lington Heights. This outage is to re-struct ure and increase the size of electric equipment serving that area.

Virginia Electric and Power Company had the largest number of employees participating and raised the most money of any corporate employee team in the nation in the 1983 March of Dimes Walk Amer ica Campaign. The 5.386 walkers representing Vepco in the Walk America teamwalk on April 24 raised about 215,000 -- more than twice the amount contributed by the next highest utility. Among all types of corporations. Bank of America was second, with slightly less than 200,000, Last year-with more than 1.000 employees and their famiti raising 50,000 in the teathwalK  vepco contributed the largest amount of any utility in the nation. Vepcos effort this year was coordinated by Nancy Cross, director of office services, and Tim Sutor, senior office systems analyst, both in the management informa tion services department at the companys headquarters in Rich mond. Cross and Sutor will represent Vepco at the March of Dimes National Telethon against birth defects scheduled for July 3-4 in Los Angeles. The 21-hour telethon will feature such performers as George Buriis, Bob Hope, Sally Kellerman and Gregory Peek. An interview with Cross and Sutor ia scheduled to be broadcast on Monday, July 4, between 1050 and 1135 a.m. over television station WDCA, Channel 20, Washington, D.C.

Virginia Electric and Power Company for magazines and a mailing campaign designed to promote Southside Virginia as a preferred location for industry. Two Vepco representatives, Leon L. Bond and Wfesley W. Gray, were in Appomattox Mon day talking with Dr. S. R. Law- son Town mayor W. Lloyd Vaughan, editor and publisher of the TIMES-VIRGINIAN and others. Their purpose  to es tablish working contact with groups actively working to bring industry to this area. Bond is director of the Industrial Deve lopment - Area Development De partment and Gray is a mem ber of the Area Development De partment, of VepCo.

VIRGINIA ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY   y j

VERY WOMAN who goes shopping . . . every man who looks over the pile of monthly bills . . . knows that the cost of living has increased substantially in the last few years.  The one bright spot in the family budget is the low cost of Electricity! You can still buy Electricity at pre war prices  the lowest in Vepco history! VIRGINIA ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY

Vepco Proposes New Rato For Churches Virginia Electric and Power Company filed today with the State Corporation Commission I a proposed new rate for churches. j-. The new rate would I recognize the unique usage patterns of some churches, synagogues and similar institu- I tions, said William W. Berry, executive vice president. It is also an additional step in Vepcos time-of-usage pricing program. Under the program, chimbes may volunteer for a one-year period to be billed on the basis of the time that energy is used. The schedule filed with the I Commission for its approval I ! would provide a basic customer  charge of 17.50 plus an energy I charge of 2.39 cents per kilowatthour for on-peak usage I and 1,50 cents per kwh for 11 off-peak usage. On-peak hours are 900-a.m. - 900 p.m. EST 1000 a.m. - 1000 p.m. EDT Monday through Friday. All trther hours, including week ends, are off-peak. The proposed schedule also  includes an on-peak kilowatt, demand charge, Peak demand determ ines the amount of generation the company must I build. For the summer billing months of June through September, if is 7.37 per kw j for the first 200 kw of on-peak demand and 8.87 per kw for additional kw on-peak demand. Iri the winter billing months of October through May, the first 200 kw of on-peak demand is priced at 4.91 per kw with i additional on-peak demand priced at 6.41-per kw. There is no kilowatt démand charge for off-peak demand which includes weekends. Since the program is just beginning, we cannot estimate how many church would benefit by volunteering for, the new rate Mr. Berry said. Church es that conduct all or most of their activities on weekends are in the best position for savings, he said.  He added that the program would be administered on an individual basis on Vepco. Any church interested in this program should contact the nearest Vepco office. A personal visit by a Vepco representative, will be made to assist the church in estimating that time-of-usqge ateté would duw e on- - tS churchs energy costs. - The-timing of file program will depend on the number of churches participating and the availability and delivery of new time-of-usage m eters, Mr. Berry said.

document.text: Vepco customers west of the Town of Appomattox wifi be without electric service for three hours on the morning of Saturday, Dec. 4, 1976, while crews convert lines in the area to a higher voltage. Service will be interrupted at 630 a,in. and will be restored by approximat ely 930a.m. The area to be affected begins just west of Maudes Restaurant and extends west through the communities of Spout Spring and Concord. Several subdivisions along R t. 691 including Falling River Acres, W alton Place and Country Club Estates wifi also be affected. The area northwest of Appomattox along Rt. 656 will not be affected, however. D . C. Stables, Jr ., District Manager of Virginia Electric and Power Company,, ?in Farmville, said the work being done, is necessary to provide for future load growth. He noted that growth in this area bad been rapid in recent years with numerous new homes and

document.text: Two widely known and res pected leaders in the field of ag riculture and power supply will be guest speakers at the 34th an nual meeting of the membership of the Southside Electric Co operative to be held at the Crewe headquarters on Saturday, Sept ember 11th. The tone of the meeting will be set by Charles B. Shuman, past president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, who will talk on Agriculture, Industry and Government. . His address will be the first feature of the program and will speak shortly after 1 p.m. T. Justin Moore, Jr., presi dent of the Virginia Electric and Power Company, will be the highlight of the business meet ing period when he speaks on  Power for the People . He will speak at 215 p.m. The annual meeting gets un derway at 10 a.m. with re gistration at the Cooperatives pavilion just west of the Crewe SEC headquarters on Rt 460.

document.text: TO THE HOMEMAKER By Sara W. Baldwin, Home Economist, Virginia Electric and Power Company With all the heavy, rich Christ mas foods fruits certainly can be a welcome change, and here are some new ideas on serving fruits. TheseFruit N Juice cocktails and finger fruits require no silver, fill the bill for fruit first in the living room. Fruit and Juice Cocktails Arrange several pieces of fruit in each fruit glass then add juice to fill. Have a few toothpicks ready on the same tray for those who wish to spear theix fruit. Gingerale over seedless grapes Cranberry juice cocktail over can ed apricot chunks Lemonade or limeade use frozen concentrated over orange sec tions and pineapple chunks Cider over apple slices or canned pineapple Pineapple juice over frozen straw berries cut frozen into cubes Cranberry juice cocktail over orange sections, canned sliced peaches, or pineapple chunks. Finger Fruits Choose one or more of these for fruit hors de oeuvres platter. They can pinch-hit for first or salad course. Pineapple chunks on toothpicks, to dip into Mace topped sour cream or deviled ham n cheese spread. Apple or pear wedges, dipped into lemon juice, then topped with sharp cheese spread or mixture of Roque fort and cream cheese. Banana spears, dipped into lemon juice, then rolled in chopped nuts. Prunes, stuffed with crunchy peanut butter. Avocado cubes on toothpicks, dip ped into lemon juice or tangy cock tail sauce to dunk in grated process American cheese. M M

document.text: to the Appomattox area within the next several weeks. U. 0. Rock Rothgeb, Serviceman for the Virginia Electric and Power Company in the Appomattox area for the past 26 years, will retire at the end of December. Mr. Rothgeb and his wife were honored at a dinner in Farmville on December 13 attended by a large group of his fellow Vepco employees in the Farmville District. Citing Mr. Rothgeb for his many years of faithful service, 1. . Stables, Jr., Farmville District Mana ger, commented, Youve miss ed countless hours of sleep through the years repairing storm trouble and we appreci ate what youve done. We also appreciate the thousands of telephone calls Mrs. Rothgeb has handled while you were out making repairs. Mr. Rothgeb, a native of Prince Edward County, joined Vepco in Farmville in July, 1945. He had just returned from Army service in Europe where he received the Purple Heart with cluster and the Bronze Star. After three years in Farmville, he was assigned in 1948 to the Appomattox Servicemans position. Succeeding Rothgeb as Ap pomattox Serviceman will be Ronnie L. Stevens, presently a Vepco Lineman in Altavisita. A native of Halifax County, Stevens joined Vepco in Peters burg in 1967 and transferred to Altavista a year later. He and his wife, Gaye, and two children, Scott, age 12, and Karen, age 10, expect to move

document.text: TO DEDICATE STATION The Virginia Electric and Power Company will dedicate its new York- town Power Station at formal cere monies on Tuesday, September 10, Erwin H. Will, president, has an nounced. The dedication, which will feature luncheon and guided tours of the station, is expected to draw large numbers of people from die Peninsula area. The dedication will mark the of ficial open ng of the newest power station of he Vepco system. The first unit, rated at 150,000 kilo watts, began production of electri city in mid-July. A second unit,! scheduled for completion late in 1958, will double the stations capa bility.

document.text: The Virginia Electric and Power Company announced today that in order to make repairs on the Ap pomattox feeder line, it will be necessary to interrupt the electric service in t his area on Sunday, Sept. 26, from 130 P. M. to 430 P . M., weather permitting. The Virginia Electric and Power Company
The Virginia Electric and Power Company

The State Corporation of Vir ginia will soon be asked to issue a certificate of public conven ience and necessity for a future high voltage transmission line proposed by Virginia Electric and Power Company. The Companys application, which will be filed in the near future, is designed to help the Company offset ris ing costs and meet the growing demands for electric service in Virginia where 748,000 of its 810,- 000 customers are located. The Company also serves parts of West Virginia and North Caro lina. The Commission is expect ed to hold ia hearing on the Com panys application. The Companys constant search for additional operating econo mies is reflected in the fact that it has had only one general rate increase in the past 37 years and its most recent rate reduction was in December 1962. Rates re duced at that time will result in a savings of 3,000,000 per year to Vepcos electric customers.

document.text: The Board of Directors of Virginia Electric and Power Company today announced the election of S. Brooks Robert son as secretary of the company effective July 1. Mr. Robertson, presently as sistant secretary, succeeds Linwood G. Parrish, who con tinues as vice president-fin ance. The company also announced the appointment of Daniel A. Hillsman, Jr. as assistant se cretary, succeeding Mr. Rob ertson. A native of Richmond, Mr. Robertson joined Vepcoinl938, the year he was graduated from the University of Richmond with a B. S. degree in business ad ministration. He held a number of positions in various sections this section. The existing limits also will be retained on two other sec tions of highway in Northern Virginia. One is the half-mile segment of 1-66 from Lynn St. to the District of Columbia line in Arlington the other is a 3.4 mile section of 1-66 west of Marshall in Fauquier County. Also included on the list for retention of present speed lim its are two segments of inter state routes in the Richmond area. These include the 3.4- mile segment of 1-64 between the Richmond-Petersburg Turnpike downtown and a point just east of Va. 33, and a 1.7 mile section of 1-95 connecting with the northern end of the Richmond- Petersburg Turn pike. Earlier, the turnpike author ity announced plans to retain existing speed limits on the en tire distance of its facility. The existing maximum limi ts will be retained on five sections of the interstate sys tem in the Hampton Roads area. These include the 8.4 miles of 1-64 between Newgate Road and the Curlew Drive overpass in Virginia Beach 4.5 miles of 1-264 connection with 1-64 and the Virginia Beach -Norfolk Expressway a 2.1 mile section of 1-264 between US 17 and Washington Street in Ports mouth the 1.5 miles of 1-464 which have been completed and the 2.8 miles of 1-64 between Va. 134 and the Hampton Roads Bridge - Tunnel toll plaza in Hampton. In addition, the present lim its will be kept on the 1.5 mile Interstate 381 spur at Bristol.
